method.name: NICGAR

reference.ref: D. Martín, J. Alcalá-Fdez, A. Rosete and F. Herrera. NICGAR: a Niching Genetic Algorithm to Mine a Diverse Set of Interesting Quantitative Association Rules. Information Sciences, 355-356:208-228 (2016).

generalDescription.type: Association Rules Mining by means of Genetic Algorithms
generalDescription.objective: The niching genetic algorithms mines a diverse and reduced set of positive and negative quatitative association rules that are easy to understand, interesting and which provide a good coverage of the dataset.
generalDescription.howWork: The genetic learning is performed iteratively until a maximum number of evaluations is reached. First, the algorithm generates an initial population with a good coverage of the dataset. Then an offspring population is generated from the current population by selection, crossover and mutation. The punishment mechanism is applied to each new individual, penalizing the ﬁtness value of an individual if it belongs to a niche of the solutions of the EP and is not better than the corresponding solution of the EP according to the ﬁtness function. The next population is constructed from the current and offspring populations, and, if necessary, the EP is updated based on the niches from the current population and the restarting process is applied. At the end, the EP is returned.

parameterSpec.param: Number of Evaluations: the maximum number of evaluations to accomplish.
Population Size: the population size to handle after each generation.
Probability of Mutation: the probability of mutation.
The factor of amplitude for each attribute of the dataset: the amplitude factor related to each attribute of the database.
Niching Threshold: the degree of similarity of two rules to be in the same niches.
Quality Threshold: the percentage of the average ﬁtness of the individuals from the EP that an individual has to overcome to be added in the EP.
Difference threshold: the difference between the current population and previous population for which the population is restarted.

method.example:
Problem type: Association Rules Method: NICGAR Dataset: basketball Parameters: default values (seed = 1286082570)
After the execution of RunKeel.jar we can see XML representations of the mined association rules along with the values concerning the measures of interest, respectively, in:
"results/Asso-NICGAR.basketball/result0s0.tra"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rules> <rule id="0"> <antecedents> <attribute name="points_per_minuteReal" value="NOT [0.26839999999999997, 0.8291]"/> </antecedents> <consequents> <attribute name="time_playedReal" value="NOT [17.4601, 40.71]"/> </consequents> </rule> ... ... ... ... </rules>
"results/Asso-NICGAR.basketball/result0s0.tst"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <values> <rule id="0" rule_support="0.08" antecedent_support="0.08" consequent_support="0.22" confidence="1" lift="4.58" conviction="Infinity" certainFactor="1" netConf="0.85" yulesQ="1" nAttributes="2"/> ... ... ... ... </values>
"results/Asso-NICGAR.basketball/result0s0e0.txt"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <values> Support antecedent_support consequent_support Confidence Lift Conv CF NetConf YulesQ nAttributes distOC 0.02 0.02 0.02 1 96 Infinity 1 1 1 2 0.89 ... ... ... ... </values>
We can also see some information on-screen:
Initialization Computing Generation 1 Computing Generation 2 ... ... ... ... Computing Generation 609 done.
Number of trials = 100092
Algorithm Finished
3.54 seconds
